Econometrics, a combination of mathematics, statistics and computation which is used to analyze economic economic data is useless in isolation, it's relevance lies in it supporting a specific economic theory or comparing competing theories. Aris Spanos once said,   No economic theory was ever abandoned because it was rejected by some empirical econometric test, nor was a clear cut decision between competing theories made in the light of evidence of such a test.  In this sense, econometrics will never lose its relevance because a theory without evidence is just speculation and econometrics or statistical analysis in general is the only tool that can provide that evidence. Hundreds of false and ludicrous theories are rejected every year because of some or the other flaw in their econometric model and economics will be flooded with thousands more if econometrics is not used to verify them.  This is not to say econometrics is all encompassing. As economics is evolving, so are the methods to analyze economic data and conduct economic research. There is increasing emphasis on experimental economics and high quality research papers have been published using calibration and simulations. Econometrics is now the secondary empirical method for many areas of economics. It is still useful for its simplicity compared to its alternatives and this gives it greater acceptance though. Paul Semuelson summarized it the best when he said,   Even if a scientific regularity were less accurate than intuitive hunches of a virtuoso, the fact that it can be put into operation by thousands of people who are not virtuosos gives it transcendental importance.   An undergrad economics student can run regressions, while a normal undergrad without special training cannot run simulations or calibrations. Confirmation bias can give me hundreds of spurious correlation but it is upto me to not pay any heed to them unless I know how to correctly use econometrics and rely on my theory based judgment when thinking whether to accept or reject the results of a regression.
